question: To what extent do the following factors enhance your ability to undertake regular or increase your physical activity?

options.text: Support from family and friends - I have someone I can exercise with.
Emphasis on the importance of physical activity from healthcare professionals - I have received enough information from my doctors on the benefits of exercise for me.
Knowledge of current physical activity recommendations - I know where to find trustworthy exercise recommendations and how to adopt them.
Access to physical activity options - There are enough places to exercise (e.g., gyms, fitness clubs, parks) in the area where I live.
Development of a routine - I have developed a daily/weekly exercising routine which motivates me to continue exercising.
Recent medical diagnosis - A medical diagnosis that I received acted as a wake-up call to make changes towards a more physically active lifestyle.
Role modeling - If I exercise frequently, it is more likely that my children will do the same.
Everyday life, energy and strength are improved - I have enough energy to exercise frequently.

Support from healthcare professionals to tailor activities to an individual’s level of physical functioning - I have received advice and/or an exercise programme which is tailored to my needs and/or diagnosis.

question: Which of the following best describes the area you live in?

options.text: Rural area (Area with lots of nature and open spaces, with fewer people and buildings than urban or suburban areas.)

Suburban area (Area where people live just outside of a city or town. There are lots of houses in suburban areas, but not as many other buildings as urban areas—maybe just one or two small shops or stores.)
Urban area (Area in a city or town: lots of people live there, and there are lots of different kinds of buildings close together.)

question: During the last 7 days, how much time did you spend sitting on an average day?
hint: This question is about the time you spent sitting on weekdays during the last 7 days.  Include time spent at work, at home, while doing course work and during leisure time. This may include time spent sitting at a desk, visiting friends, reading, or sitting or lying down to watch television.

question: During the last 7 days, on how many days did you do moderate physical activities like carrying light loads, bicycling at a regular pace, or doubles tennis?  Do not include walking.
hint: Think about all the moderate activities that you did in the last 7 days.  Moderate activities refer to activities that take moderate physical effort and make you breathe somewhat harder than normal. Examples of moderate aerobic physical activities: -Moderate intensity recreational activities: brisk walking, hiking, bicycling, low impact aerobics, dancing. -Moderate intensity individual sports: swimming. -Moderate intensity team sports: competitive volleyball.) Examples of moderate muscle-strengthening activities: Yoga, weight training, housework that involves intense scrubbing and cleaning.)

question: How much time did you usually spend doing moderate physical activities on one of those days?
hint: Think about all the moderate activities that you did in the last 7 days.  Moderate activities refer to activities that take moderate physical effort and make you breathe somewhat harder than normal. Examples of moderate aerobic physical activities: -Moderate intensity recreational activities: brisk walking, hiking, bicycling, low impact aerobics, dancing. -Moderate intensity individual sports: swimming. -Moderate intensity team sports: competitive volleyball.) Examples of moderate muscle-strengthening activities: Yoga, weight training, housework that involves intense scrubbing and cleaning.)

question: Please specify what medical condition you have been diagnosed with.

options.text: Cardiovascular Diseases (e.g.hypertension, coronary artery disease (heart disease), heart failure, stroke)
Endocrine and Metabolic Disorders (e.g. type 2 diabetes mellitus 2, hyper-/hypothyroidism, dyslipidemia, non-alcoholic fatty liver disease, metabolic syndrome)
Respiratory Diseases (e.g. chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), asthma)
Musculoskeletal Disorders (e.g. osteoarthritis, rheumatoid arthritis, osteoporosis)
Gastrointestinal Disorders (e.g. inflammatory bowel disease, chronic liver disease, irritable bowel syndrome (IBS), gastrointestinal reflux)
Kidney and Urinary Tract Disorders (e.g. chronic kidney disease (CKD), kidney stones)
Autoimmune Diseases (e.g. lupus, celiac disease, psoriasis, type 1 diabetes mellitus)
Hematologic and Blood Disorders (anemia/ chronic anemia, sickle cell disease)

question: During the last 7 days, on how many days did you do vigorous physical activities like heavy lifting, digging, aerobics, or fast bicycling?
hint: Think about all the vigorous activities that you did in the last 7 days.  Vigorous physical activities refer to activities that take hard physical effort and make you breathe much harder than normal. Examples of vigorous aerobic physical activities: -Vigorous intensity recreational activities: jogging/running, mountain climbing, brisk bicycling, high impact step aerobics, brisk dancing. -Vigorous intensity individual sports: race walking, vigorous swimming, competitive tennis. -Vigorous intensity team sports: competitive basketball, soccer/football. Examples of vigorous muscle-strengthening activities: Vigorous intensity martial arts, heavy lifting, power yoga.)

question: Please select how long it takes for you to walk from your place of residence to the following
To what extent do the following factors enhance your ability to follow a healthier diet?

options.text: Access to good-quality and freshly produced, low in calories products
Availability of offers and/or coupons that make healthy food more affordable
A helping hand with food preparation
Support from family and friends - other members of my family choose the same healthy options, changes are easier in a family level
Emphasis on the importance of a healthy diet from healthcare professionals
Support of knowledge on current healthy eating recommendations - it is good to have someone to guide me on where i can find the recommendations
Accountability partner - it is easier to follow a healthier diet when i have a partner/buddy i can account/commit to
Receiving support/solutions/proposals from healthcare professionals (primary care physician, dietitian, physiotherapist)
Skills on healthy food meal preparation
A recent medical diagnosis - a wake-up call to change towards a healthier diet
Development of a routine - a daily routine regarding healthy diet provides discipline and willingness to persist to a healthier diet
Everyday life, energy and strength are improved - I have more energy in my daily life
Role modelling - if i follow a healthier diet it is also more probable for my children to do the same

How much time did you usually spend doing vigorous physical activities on one of those days?
hint: Think about all the vigorous activities that you did in the last 7 days.  Vigorous physical activities refer to activities that take hard physical effort and make you breathe much harder than normal. Examples of vigorous aerobic physical activities: -Vigorous intensity recreational activities: jogging/running, mountain climbing, brisk bicycling, high impact step aerobics, brisk dancing. -Vigorous intensity individual sports: race walking, vigorous swimming, competitive tennis. -Vigorous intensity team sports: competitive basketball, soccer/football. Examples of vigorous muscle-strengthening activities: Vigorous intensity martial arts, heavy lifting, power yoga.)

question: How much time did you usually spend walking on one of those days?
hint: Think about the time you spent walking in the last 7 days.  This includes at work and at home, walking to travel from place to place, and any other walking that you have done solely for recreation, sport, exercise, or leisure.

question: How many cigarettes/other tobacco products do you smoke/use on an average day?
How many steps did you usually walk on one of those days?
hint: Think about the time you spent walking in the last 7 days.  This includes at work and at home, walking to travel from place to place, and any other walking that you have done solely for recreation, sport, exercise, or leisure. You can check the number of steps that you walked on other apps that you may have, such as Apple Health or through your smartwatch.

question: During the last 7 days, on how many days did you walk for leisure or to travel from place to place?
hint: Think about the time you spent walking in the last 7 days.  This includes at work and at home, walking to travel from place to place, and any other walking that you have done solely for recreation, sport, exercise, or leisure.

question: To what extent do the following factors may limit your ability to undertake regular or increase your physical activity?

options.text: Lack of time and competing priorities - I don’t have the time needed to exercise due to work, family and/or other engagements.
Lack of motivation to undertake exercise in the short-term - It is difficult for me to find motivation to exercise on a day-to-day basis.
Lack of motivation to stick to exercising routines in the long-term - It is difficult for me to find motivation to keep on exercising for 6 months or more.
Feel fatigue and/or lack of energy - I often feel too tired to exercise.
Competition with activities promoting a sedentary lifestyle - I prefer to watch television and/or engage in hobbies that do not involve exercising.

Lack of support from healthcare professionals to tailor activities to an individual’s level of physical functioning - I tried to exercise but was unable to complete exercises due to my diagnosis and/or my current health condition.
Lack of exercising skills - I don’t know how to exercise effectively.
Lack of physical fitness - I feel weak or get easily tired when exercising.
Concern due to physical condition (e.g., disability, chronic illness) - My health is not good enough to exercise.
Lack of support from family and friends - I have no one I can exercise with.
Lack of belief in the effectiveness of physical activity for preventing lifestyle-related diseases - I don’t think that exercising will help me to improve my overall health.
Barriers in the built-up environment and geographical isolation - There is no place to exercise that I can easily access.
I believe I do not need to exercise because my overall health is good enough.
Lack of knowledge on current physical activity recommendations - I don’t know where to find trustworthy exercise recommendations and how to adopt them.
Fear of injury - I’m afraid that I may get hurt or injured when exercising.
Social norms and stigma - I don’t feel welcome in a fitness club and/or other places of public exercise.
Weather conditions - It is difficult for me to exercise due to the weather conditions (e.g., it is too hot/rainy) in the area where I live.
Concerns about safety - I feel that it is unsafe for me to access public exercise spaces or exercise in these in the area where I live (e.g., to walk to/exercise in local parks).
Feel uncomfortable to exercise in public - My appearance has changed after the diagnosis and the treatment undertaken and I feel uncomfortable to exercise in front of others.
Accuracy of information regarding physical activity - I do not know if I can trust information I find from the internet or social media on how to exercise.

To what extent do the following factors limit your ability to follow a healthier diet?

options.text: High availability of high-calorie and fast-food products
Lack or limited access to good-quality and freshly produced, low in calories products
Lack of time and competing priorities (work, family, hobbies)
Lack of support from family and friends - other members of my family do not choose healthy options

Difficulties in avoiding unhealthy foods in local community settings or at gatherings (business, family) - unhealthy options are usually more than the healthy ones in family gatherings or business meals
Lack of support/solutions/proposals from healthcare professionals (primary care physician, dietitian, physiotherapist)
Lack of knowledge and skills regarding the necessary steps to implement healthy lifestyle principles
Lack of knowledge on current healthy eating recommendations
Lack of skills on healthy food meal preparation
Accuracy of information regarding healthy eating - I don’t know if I can trust information I find from the internet or the social media
Adjusting habits requires a lot of effort
Lack of motivation to make changes
Lack of belief in the efficacy of healthy diet for preventing lifestyle-related diseases
